content:
Macaque and MK huddled behind a rock as the sounds of battle intensified. They could hear the clash of weapons, the sound of fists hitting flesh, and the occasional roar of a monkey. Macaque closed his eyes and focused on his magic, trying to summon as much power as he could.

"Stay behind me," he said to MK, who nodded silently. "We have to be ready for anything."

Suddenly, the sounds of battle stopped. Macaque opened his eyes and cautiously peeked over the rock. He could see Wukong and Nezha standing facing each other, both panting heavily. Nezha's armor was dented and his weapon looked like it had taken a beating, but he still stood tall and confident.

"You can't beat me, Wukong," Nezha said, his voice steady despite his exhaustion. "I'm here to take back what you stole."

Wukong growled and bared his teeth. "I didn't steal anything. Everything I have, I took by my own strength."

"That's not true," Nezha replied. "You stole the immortality pills from the Queen Mother of the West. You're not supposed to have them, and you know it."

Wukong hesitated for a moment, his face contorting with anger. "So what if I did?" he shouted. "I deserve them more than anyone else. I'm the Great Sage Equal to Heaven! I'm unstoppable!"

Macaque frowned and stepped out from behind the rock, his hands crackling with magic. "You're not unstoppable, Wukong," he said. "And you're not invincible. We've all seen that now."

Wukong turned to face him, his eyes blazing with fury. "You think you're so clever, Macaque," he sneered. "But you're just a weak, pathetic monkey. You can't even stand up to me, let alone defeat me."

Macaque didn't flinch. "I may be weaker than you, Wukong, but I have something you don't," he said. "I have honor. And I have friends who will stand by me, no matter what."

Wukong snorted. "Friends? You mean that worthless human boy? He's nothing. He's not even worth the trouble it took to capture him."

MK stepped out from behind the rock as well, his eyes blazing with defiance. "I'm not worthless," he said. "And neither is Macaque. You're the one who's weak, Wukong. You're weak because you're afraid to face your own flaws. You're afraid to admit that you're not perfect, that you can be defeated. But you know what? That's what makes us strong. The ability to admit our mistakes and learn from them."

Wukong glared at MK, his fists clenching. For a moment, it looked like he was going to attack, but then he hesitated. "You think you're so smart, don't you?" he said. "But you don't know anything. You don't know what it's like to be powerful, to be respected, to be feared. You're just a weak little boy, and you always will be."

MK stood his ground, his eyes locked on Wukong's. "Maybe I am just a weak little boy," he said. "But I'm not afraid to stand up to bullies like you. And I'm not afraid to fight for what's right."

Wukong stared at him for a moment longer, and then he turned and stormed off, his monkeys following him. MK and Macaque watched him go, their hearts pounding.

"Are you okay?" Mac
